repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Economic Competitiveness
            Adjustment Loan, Second Economic Competitiveness Adjustment
            Loan and Third Economic Competitiveness Adjustment Loan Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for all three
            projects--the Economic Competitiveness Adjustment Loan (Loan
            No. 4096), the Second Economic Competitiveness Adjustment
            Loan (Loan No. 4461), and the Third Economic Competitiveness
            Adjustment Loan (Loan No. 7094)--are as follows:  Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is modest; World Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory.  The main lessons are: 1) Tunisia's
            successful economic performance has been due to three
            attributes: ownership and broad political consensus, a
            well-developed human resource base, and a stable
            macroeconomic environment. 2)  Experience in privatization
            and the financial sector shows the need for the Bank and the
            development partners to stay the course and show flexibility
            in their support, provided there is evidence of genuine and
            sustained reform efforts. For example, by accepting partial
            reforms in some areas, and building on partial successes to
            deepen them in subsequent operations, the support from the
            Bank and other partners was ultimately effective. Patience,
            perseverance and flexibility paid off. 3) An important
            lesson for other small emerging countries seeking to lay the
            foundations for sustainable growth and poverty reduction is
            the success of Tunisia in creating a competitive economy by
            the coordinated use o f macro and structural policies and reforms.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Second Economic Competitiveness
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Economic
            Competitiveness Adjustment Loan Project in Tunisia (ECAL II)
            is rated satisfactory and sustainability is likely. Both the
            and Borrower performances are regarded as satisfactory. ECAL
            II incorporated the lessons of ECAL I by focusing narrowly
            on upgrading the performance of the financial sector and
            specifically the banking sector. Given the importance of the
            banking system in the Tunisian financial sector, it was
            correctly chosen as the principal target of reforms. An
            extensive reform package for the insurance sector was not
            included under this loan because although necessary, the
            reforms could not have been effectively implemented during
            the ECAL II timeframe. Instead, preparatory work for
            insurance sector reforms was done during ECAL II, and the
            reform measures have been included as part of ECAL III. The
            series of ECAL adjustment operations in Tunisia have
            demonstrated the value of appropriately targeted and
            sequenced reform measures in the long-term development of a
            country's economy. One particular weakness in ECAL II
            also provides an important lesson: it is crucial to obtain a
            firm, binding commitment from all parties having decision
            authority over actions targeted by the operation. The
            privatization of the merged bank was included as a condition
            for the release of the second tranche. Given that the
            Borrower did not have exclusive control of the merger
            decision, this measure should not have been included.

TF036739-TUNISIA - ECAL II, DEBT

5086067.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Second Economic Competitiveness
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Economic Competitiveness
            Adjustment Loan will support financial sector reforms,
            supplementing ongoing reforms in the real sector. The loan
            will be disbursed in two tranches, with parallel financing
            from the European Union and the African Development Bank.
            The financial sector reform program, within the context of
            the Free Trade Association (FTA) with the European Union,
            aims at upgrading critical performances among the service
            industry, thus contributing to an economic growth.
            Specifically, the project will address the financial
            strengthening of the banking system, while improving loan
            collateral and foreclosure procedures. Bank privatization
            and consolidation are policy measures included in the
            project, as is the modernization of banking law and
            prudential regulations. Comprehensive reforms of the
            government securities market will promote monetary control,
            while regulatory frameworks of non-bank financial
            intermediation will be enhanced. The project will benefit
            the banking system, and, while the presence of the
            Government will be reduced, this will contribute to a
            stronger market discipline in the management of state-owned
            banks. The banking system's capacity to adjust to
            external and internal shocks, will also benefit from the
            project, as will greater savings mobilization, through
            financial intermediaries.
